thread.title: The Atlantic Cuts Ties With Writer Who Likened Abortion to Capital Crime

author: Benjamin Mullin
title: The Atlantic Cuts Ties With Writer Who Likened Abortion to Capital Crime
text:
30 COMMENTS The Atlantic has severed ties with a high-profile conservative commentator after he was criticized on social media for caustic antiabortion comments he made in 2014.
The magazine “parted ways” with Kevin Williamson, a former writer for National Review whose first byline appeared in the Atlantic earlier this week, after editor in chief Jeffrey Goldberg learned of new information about his history of controversial comments, Mr. Goldberg said in a memo.
“Kevin is a gifted writer, and he has been nothing but professional in all of our interactions,” Mr. Goldberg said. “But I have come to the conclusion that the Atlantic is not the best fit for his talents, and so we are parting ways.”
The Atlantic declined to comment beyond Mr. Goldberg’s memo. 
Mr. Williamson disputed Mr. Goldberg’s account of the events.
“It is not the case that ‘we parted ways,’ as Jeff Goldberg put it. It is the case that he fired me,” Mr. Williamson said. He called the phrase “a detestable euphemism” that “illuminates the character of the entire sorry affair.”
Mr. Williamson is the latest commentator to be ousted from a mainstream publication after information about their history surfaced.
In February , the New York Times said it had hired tech writer Quinn Norton as an opinion writer. A social-media firestorm erupted over her friendship with a neo-Nazi hacker and over her past tweets and retweets containing racist and antigay slurs. By the end of the day, Ms. Norton said she would no longer be joining the publication.
The announcement of Mr. Williamson’s hire at the Atlantic late last month drew scrutiny from the liberal watchdog group Media Matters .
The organization pointed to a 2014 tweet by Mr. Williamson in which he said abortion should be “treated like any other premeditated homicide,” adding that he viewed hanging as a potential punishment.
Mr. Goldberg initially defended Mr. Williamson’s hire. In a memo to staff last month, Mr. Goldberg wrote that Mr. Williamson’s “trollish” tweets shouldn’t be considered in isolation and touted Mr. Williamson’s reporting skills.
In the memo, Mr. Goldberg said the Atlantic “should be a big tent for ideas and argument” and singled out ideological diversity as an area of particular focus.
On Wednesday, Media Matters highlighted a podcast interview released in September 2014 with Mr. Williamson that suggested his tweet wasn’t an isolated comment.
In the interview he said, regarding abortion, “I would totally go with treating it like any other crime, up to and including hanging.”
That interview caused the Atlantic to re-evaluate its relationship with Mr. Williamson, Mr. Goldberg wrote.
“The language he used in this podcast—and in my conversations with him in recent days—made it clear that the original tweet did, in fact, represent his carefully considered views,” he wrote.
Ben Shapiro, a conservative commentator and editor in chief of the Daily Wire, criticized Mr. Williamson’s firing on Twitter, writing that it represented an attempt by “the left” to narrow “the spectrum of acceptable discourse.” In a follow-up article for the Daily Wire , Mr. Shapiro wrote that marginalizing writers like Mr. Williamson “will result in the utter polarization of politics in the worst possible ways.”
